bibl.title: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, September 26, 1929

div1.p: Carter does not see the need to provide weekly updates as she is still waiting for Frost to resume work on the manuscript. She also fills him in on her activities since early August.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, September 26, 1929
div1.opener:
Book, Misel
Report, Russell.
“Dunlora,” Box 453,
Charlottesville, Virginia,
September 26, 1929.
Dear Doctor Russell:
div1.p:
After my return to Washington early in August, at which time,
as I then wrote you, I had hoped and expected the final editing on
Father's book would be resumed, I was looking forward to again writing
to you regularly as to the progress of the work. Shortly thereafter, however,
while spending some time in Baltimore with the Frosts, Dr. Frost told me
that--although he intended resuming the final editing of the History of
Yellow Fever as soon as he possibly could--he was not then in a position to
take up the work, as other things had accumulated during his absence in
Europe and said that you were perfectly aware of this fact.

In view therefore of Dr. Frost's statement that he had informed you
as to the status of the work of the final editing, I hardly felt that it was
unnecessary to take up your time by writing regularly as to what Miss Brown
and I were doing, although we have been having a very busy time.

The reference cards being already, for the most part, verified and
revised as carefully as possible, we have been, in the main, concentrating our
efforts on the library cards in the endeavor to settle various technical points
as to clearness and form. Their accuracy, of course, Miss Brown had established
long since. In this work we again had the great good fortune to have the help
of Dr. Martel, Chief of the Catalogue Division of the Library of Congress, who
is, as you know, an outstanding authority on things of this sort. He went over
the last 3/5 of the cards with us and we hope to have his advice upon the
others as soon as Dr. Frost can let us have them. Dr. Martel told us that the
cards were in excellent form and really needed no alterations from a librarian's
standpoint. This, of course, I owe to Miss Brown. He, nevertheless, made some
some
-2-
very valuable suggestions as to several changes in the form of some of these
cards, which Miss Brown has already carried out, and which, we think, will make
them clearer to those readers of the History of Yellow Fever who wish to consult
our original sources.

Re our illustrative material, I had hoped to be able to discuss the matter
at some length with Dr. Frost,in order to decide on the best way in which to
present it, before again taking up the matter with Mr. Bushnell of the Smithsonian
Institution and those of the specialists in this line of work to whom he had
promised to introduce me. Dr. Frost was, however, too busy during my stay in
Baltimore for me to even attempt to begin the discussion of this subject. There
will, however, be plenty of time later to attend to any minor changes (if such are
deemed advisable) in our present material for illustrations without in anyway holding up the com-
pletion of the MS.

Miss Brown and I came to “Dunlora” a few days ago, bringing with us
duplicates of cards and other material in the possession of Dr. Frost in order to
continue the work here. I am hoping each day to hear that Dr. Frost has been
able to resume the final editing. Of this, of course,, he will advise you as
soon as (or sooner than) he does me. When once he has time for it, we know how
rapidly, as well as how excellently![unclear] he will “put things through.” I am so
very glad that you spoke to him about writing a biographic sketch of Father to
preceed the History!
With all manner of good wishes, I remain
div1.closer:
Most truly yours, Laura A. Carter Dr. Frederick F. Russell,
Director,
International Health Division
The Rockefeller Foundation,
61 Broadway,
NewYork, N. Y.
